awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Improving pedestrian visibility and safety through passive detection and direct illumination at crossings
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a more effective and less expensive pedestrian safety device that will help reduce the thousands of pedestrian deaths and hundreds of thousands of pedestrian collisions that occur in crosswalks each year. Previous research has demonstrated that the underlying shortcomings of existing traffic measures in ensuring pedestrian safety are geographically and culturally unique. An understanding of the issues and constraints experienced by communities across a wide variety of ecological and cultural climates is necessary in order to develop and deploy traffic measures.  Specifically the proposed crosswalk innovation, that effectively works to reduce and eliminate pedestrian deaths. The quality of city life depends under consideration is walkability, which in turn relies on pedestrian safety. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a technology that improves pedestrian visibility and safety through passive detection and direct illumination of pedestrians at crossings. The passive pedestrian detection system will provide real-time deterministic pedestrian traffic and pattern data.  Such data will enhance urban planners’ scientific understanding of the transportation environment. Crosswalk networks interfaced with autonomous vehicles will enhance planners’ technological understanding of the scaffolding needed for smart city infrastructure. As cities become more hectic and congested, the freedom, adequacy, and accessibility of walkability becomes an important issue. Feeling safe and being safe on a crosswalk is vital for the future transportation health. Encouraging technology that makes pedestrians visible to the traffic system may ultimately lead to viable, walkable communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project, Improving pedestrian visibility and safety through passive detection and direct illumination at crossing is at its core, an interdisiplinary endeavor between the fields of urban and transportation planning and engineering. The technology serves to provide uplighting in crosswalks across the roadway triggered by pedestrian movement across pressure plates embedded at the intersection of the roadway with the sidewalk alerting drivers of oncoming pedestrians at crosswalks. The ICorps project sought to move the project from research and development into a pilot phase of commercialization.

During the course of the project, the team interviewed more than 100 individuals from across the U.S. in customer segments that ranged from public entities to private property holders or managers to assist in determining the markety viability. From these interviews we were better able to better determine valid market segments and understand their specific needs and interests. However, it became apparent that although our value connected with their needs, we required an extensive regulatory process of evaluation and approval with a timeline for approval of approximately 3 years.  Due to this lag, the team determined that the business model was not viable.

While this approach to small, independent commercialization was not deemed feasible, the technology remains a viable entity that we encourage be more deeply considered for further development by public transportation agencies.

Modified by: Kenneth P Yocom
